user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_parse_arguments_:
```c
enum MHD_Result
MHD_parse_arguments_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      char *args,
                      MHD_ArgumentIterator_ cb,
                      void *cls)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  char *equals;
  char *amper;

  while ( (NULL != args) &&
          ('\0' != args[0]) )
  {
    size_t key_len;
    size_t value_len;
    equals = strchr (args, '=');
    amper = strchr (args, '&');
    if (NULL == amper)
    {
      /* last argument */
      if (NULL == equals)
      {
        /* last argument, without '=' */
        MHD_unescape_plus (args);
        key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             args);
        if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                          args,
                          key_len,
                          NULL,
                          0,
                          kind))
          return MHD_NO;
        break;
      }
      /* got 'foo=bar' */
      equals[0] = '\0';
      equals++;
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
      value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             equals);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        equals,
                        value_len,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      break;
    }
    /* amper is non-NULL here */
    amper[0] = '\0';
    amper++;
    if ( (NULL == equals) ||
         (equals >= amper) )
    {
      /* got 'foo&bar' or 'foo&bar=val', add key 'foo' with NULL for value */
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        NULL,
                        0,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      /* continue with 'bar' */
      args = amper;
      continue;
    }
    /* equals and amper are non-NULL here, and equals < amper,
 so we got regular 'foo=value&bar...'-kind of argument */
    equals[0] = '\0';
    equals++;
    MHD_unescape_plus (args);
    key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                         connection,
                                         args);
    MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
    value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           equals);
    if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                      args,
                      key_len,
                      equals,
                      value_len,
                      kind))
      return MHD_NO;
    args = amper;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious unreachable-code fragments were identified. Reasoning: 
- The top-level while loop is conditioned on args being non-NULL and not empty, so the loop body is reachable whenever the caller passes a non-empty args string; the function returns MHD_YES when the loop completes, which is reachable when args becomes NULL/empty or when a break executes. 
- The branch when (NULL == amper) covers the case where no '&' is present; inside it there are two mutually exclusive subcases (NULL == equals) and (equals != NULL). Both subcases are reachable depending on the input string (e.g. "foo" and "foo=bar"). The break statements are executed only when the callback returns success; the return MHD_NO statements are conditional on the callback returning MHD_NO, so there is no dead code following an unconditional jump. 
- The branch when amper is non-NULL is reachable when an '&' appears in args. Within that branch the condition (NULL == equals) || (equals >= amper) covers inputs like "foo&..." and edge cases such as "&=..." where equals may point at or after the incremented amper; these cases are reachable at runtime. The final else (equals and amper non-NULL and equals < amper) handles regular "foo=value&..." cases. All three subpaths are reachable for appropriate inputs. 
- There are no statements that follow an unconditional return, no constant-false conditionals, and no code that can never be reached due to the control-flow structure (returns/breaks/continues are all conditional or the natural loop exit). 
Given the above, there is no code in this function that is demonstrably unreachable and therefore no fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
